In-network Computation for Large-scale Federated Learning over Wireless Edge Networks

Thinh¬†Quang¬†Dinh, Diep¬†N.¬†Nguyen, Dinh Thai Hoang, Pham Tran Vu, and Eryk Dutkiewicz Preliminary results in this paper are presented at the IEEE GLOBECOM Conference, 2021¬†[1].
Abstract

Most conventional Federated Learning (FL) models are using a star network topology where all users aggregate their local models at a single server (e.g., a cloud server). That causes significant overhead in terms of both communications and computing at the server, delaying the training process, especially for large scale FL systems with straggling nodes. This paper proposes a novel edge network architecture that enables decentralizing the model aggregation process at the server, thereby significantly reducing the training delay for the whole FL network. Specifically, we design a highly-effective in-network computation framework (INC) consisting of a user scheduling mechanism, an in-network aggregation process (INA) which is designed for both primal- and primal-dual methods in distributed machine learning problems, and a network routing algorithm with theoretical performance bounds. The in-network aggregation process, which is implemented at edge nodes and cloud node, can adapt two typical methods to allow edge networks to effectively solve the distributed machine learning problems. Under the proposed INA, we then formulate a joint routing and resource optimization problem, aiming to minimize the aggregation latency. The problem turns out to be NP-hard, and thus we propose a polynomial time routing algorithm which can achieve near optimal performance with a theoretical bound. Simulation results showed that the proposed algorithm can achieve more than 99%percent\% of the optimal solution and reduce the FL training latency, up to 5.65.65.6 times w.r.t other baselines. The proposed INC framework can not only help reduce the FL training latency but also significantly decrease cloud‚Äôs traffic and computing overhead. By embedding the computing/aggregation tasks at the edge nodes and leveraging the multi-layer edge-network architecture, the INC framework can liberate FL from the star topology to enable large-scale FL.

Index Terms:
Mobile Edge Computing, Federated Learning, In-network Computation, Large-scale Distributed Learning

1 Introduction

Machine learning that enables intelligent systems has emerged as a key technology benefiting many aspects of modern society [2]. Currently, most data-driven systems collect data from local devices and then train the data at centralized cloud servers. However, user privacy, applications‚Äô latency and network overhead traffic are major concerns of this centralized solution. To address these issues, collaborative learning schemes have received considerable attention where mobile users (MUs) can build and share their machine learning models instead of sending their raw data to a centralized data center [3]. Out of these distributed learning schemes, Federated Learning (FL) has recently emerged as a promising candidate [4]. In FL, each MU iteratively computes its local model using its local training data. This local model is then sent to a cloud server and aggregated together with other local models, contributed by other MUs to produce a global model. The global model is then sent back to all the MUs and then these MUs will use it to update their new local models accordingly. This process is repeated until it is converged or an accuracy level of the learning model is reached. Since no user‚Äôs raw data is exchanged, FL facilitates machine learning in many aspects from data storage, training to data acquisition, and privacy preservation.

Although communications overhead is significantly saved by sharing local models instead of local raw data, communication cost is still a major bottleneck of FL. This is because to aggregate the global model, the centralized server generally needs to connect with a huge number of users for all their updates via star network topology [5, 6, 7, 4, 8, 9, 10]. Moreover, for advanced deep learning models [11, 12] which contain a vast amount of parameters, the size of models exchanged in networks could be very large. For example, the BERT model [11] in Natural Language Processing area is up to 1.31.31.3 GB, while VGG16 [12] in Computer Vision is more than 500500500 MB. Thus, with VGG16, it can cost about 500500500 TB for each user until the global model is converged [13]. Consequently, high communication cost can lead to (a) high transmission latency and (b) high traffic at the cloud server. To address the issues, new network architectures are needed be investigated.

High computation cost is another challenge of conventional FL models using the star network topology. Let us assume that vectors or matrices are used to store users‚Äô models for each FL iteration. With VGG16, vectors or matrices contain more than 138138138 million elements. As a result, when the number of users grows, aggregation operations at the centralized server can be very computationally costly [14, 15] in terms of processing and memory resources. For that, novel network topologies should be considered to enable large-scale FL systems.

Edge Computing (EC), an emerging distributed network architecture [3] that aims to bring cloud functions and resources (including computing, storage and networking capacities) closer to end users can be a promising solution to large scale FL. Since edge nodes (EN) possess both computation and communication capacities, edge networks can effectively support the cloud server to decentralize its communication and computing burden of model aggregation in very large scale FL networks. To exploit potential benefits of edge networks for FL models, it is necessary to develop a distributed in-network aggregation (INA) functionality that can be implemented at edge nodes of EC to liberate FL from the conventional start network topology.

In-network computation (INC) is a process of gathering and routing information through a multi-hop network, then processing data at intermediate nodes with the objective of optimizing the resource consumption [16]. Currently, the concept is well-studied for big data analytics such as MapReduce [17], Pregel [18] and DryadLINQ [19] for distributed data clusters. Three basic components of an in-network computation solution are: suitable networking protocols, effective aggregation functions and efficient ways of representing data [16]. However, INC frameworks for FL is under-studied. Moreover, edge nodes will be densely deployed in future networks [20], one can exploit this diversity by considering a scenario where an MU can associate with multiple nearby edge nodes, instead of only a single edge node. Under such a scenario, the problems of network routing and network resource allocation become more challenging.

Regarding machine learning models, e.g., classification or regression, they can be learned by solving regularized loss minimization problems in two ways: (a) by using primal methods such as Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) [4] or (2) by using the primal-dual methods such as Stochastic Dual Coordinate Ascent (SDCA) [21, 22]. Most works in FL are limited in one method [5, 6, 7, 4, 8, 9, 10, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27]. From experimental and theoretical results [9, 28], it is noted that the primal methods cost less resources, e.g. computing and storage, and can faster reach a moderate accuracy level, while the primal-dual method can provide better convergence and accuracy in the long run. As a result, to achieve high accuracy with faster convergence, instead of using vanilla SDCA, authors in [28] implemented SGD in initial rounds before executing SDCA. Therefore, a general in-network computation protocol, which can adapt to both the FL methods, is required.

Given the above, this paper proposes a novel edge network architecture and its associated in-network computation framework that enable decentralizing the model aggregation process at the server, thereby significantly reducing the training delay for the whole FL network. To this end, a highly-effective in-network computation protocol is proposed with three main components: a user scheduling mechanism, a novel in-network aggregation process which is designed for both primal- and primal-dual methods in distributed machine learning problems, and a network routing algorithm with theoretical performance bounds. The major contributions of this work are summarized as follows.

  1. 1.

    Propose a novel edge network architecture to decentralize the communication and computing burden of cloud node in FL aiming at minimizing the whole network latency. Such a network architecture is enabled by a novel in-network computation protocol consisting of an effective in-network aggregation process, a routing algorithm and a user scheduling.

  2. 2.

    Design a new user scheduling mechanism which allows a group of users to be able to send their models in advance instead of waiting for the last user finishing its local update. Based on the power law distribution of user data, this mechanism could mitigate straggler effect with a theoretical performance bound.

  3. 3.

    Develop a novel in-network aggregation process that instructs on how data are processed at edge nodes and cloud node to decentralize the global model aggregation process. The INA is designed for both primal- and dual-primal solutions to a given FL network.

  4. 4.

    Optimize the joint routing and resource allocation for MUs and ENs under the proposed architecture, thereby minimizing FL training time of the whole network. We show that the resulting mixed integer non-linear programming problem is NP-hard then propose an effective solution based on randomized rounding techniques. Simulations show that the proposed solution can achieve more than 99%percent\% of the optimal solution.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we present the related works. The system model is introduced in Section 3. Then, the user scheduling mechanism is proposed in Section 4. Section 5 presents our in-network aggregation process. Next, we formulate the network routing and resource allocation frameworks in Section 6, and propose our solution in Section 7. We then present the numerical results in Section 8 and final conclusions are drawn in Section 9.

2 Related Works

Although sharing raw local data is not required, high communication cost still remains a major obstacle in FL systems, especially given its canonical star network topology. Solutions to this issue can be divided into several directions such as compressing the local models using quantization, e.g., [5, 6], skipping unnecessary gradient calculations or global updates [7, 4], and selecting a promising user subset of each global update [8, 9, 10]. For compressing local models, MPEG-7 part 17 [5] has become a universal neural network compression standard, which is not only limited in the domain of multimedia. However, among these works [5, 6, 7, 4, 8, 9, 10], authors usually assumed that MUs can be directly connected to a single server. This star network topology assumption is impractical since it does not reflect the hierarchical structure of large-scale wireless networks. Moreover, for a large number of users, such a star topology cannot help scale up the FL system.

Edge computing is a potential infrastructure which can help to address the high communication cost of FL. Even though there are many works where edge networks are complementary to the cloud [29, 30, 31, 32], the capacities of edge networks are under explored in existing FL works [5, 6, 7, 4, 8, 9, 10, 23, 24, 25, 26]. To decentralize and redistribute the model aggregation process of FL at cloud server to edge nodes in edge networks, this article leverages the ‚Äúin-network computing" concept. Although such a concept has been well-studied for traditional machine learning paradigms where users‚Äô raw data are collected and stored at big data clusters [17, 18, 19], INC for distributed learning paradigms, e.g., FL, especially with the aid of edge computing, has not been visited.

There have been early works proposing decentralizing aggregation processes for different network architectures such hierarchical topology [27, 33], ring topology [34], and random graph [35]. However, in those works, the proposed decentralized aggregation processes can be considered as variants of either FedAvg or CoCoA. In our paper, the proposed in-network aggregation process, a component of our INC solution, can adapt to both primal and primal-dual methods. Moreover, existing works mostly focused on designing aggregation processes while network resource management and routing problems were not jointly considered. For example, in [27], users are assumed to connect with a single edge node without any alternative links. In reality with dense edge networks, MUs can associate to more than one edge nodes. Such a practical scenario calls for optimal network routing and resource allocation solution, aiming at minimizing the system latency. In this article, under the proposed INC, we formulate a joint routing and resource optimization problem, aiming to minimize the aggregation latency. The problem turns out to be NP-hard, and thus we design a polynomial time routing algorithm which can achieve near optimal performance with a proven theoretical bound. Last but not least, to address slow workers that stagnate the learning systems in these existing works [5, 6, 7, 4, 8, 9, 10, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 36, 37] (known as the straggler effect), we propose a user scheduling scheme that is the third component of our INC solution. In short, the key novelty of our work is to leverage edge networks to enable large-scale FL and liberate FL from its canonical start topology. All aforementioned works that aim to decentralize the FL process did not leverage edge networks nor address the associated challenges (e.g., routing, resource allocation, and the straggling effect).

3 System Model

Let us consider a set of KùêæK mobile users MUs, denoted by ùí¶={1,‚Ä¶,K}ùí¶1‚Ä¶ùêæ\mathcal{K}=\{1,\ldots,K\} with local datasets ùíük={ùê±i‚àà‚Ñùd,yi}i=1nksubscriptùíüùëòsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùê±ùëñsuperscript‚Ñùùëësubscriptùë¶ùëñùëñ1subscriptùëõùëò\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n_{k}} with nksubscriptùëõùëòn_{k} data points. These MUs participate in a distributed learning process by learning a shared global model from and sharing their local models (without sharing their raw data) with a cloud server. These MUs are co-located and supported by an MEC network consisting of a set of MùëÄM edge nodes (ENs), denoted by ‚Ñ≥={1,‚Ä¶,M}‚Ñ≥1‚Ä¶ùëÄ\mathcal{M}=\{1,\ldots,M\}. The edge nodes, controlled by the MEC operator, can be small cell base stations with their own communications and computing capacities [30]. ENs are connected with a cloud server via a macro base station. Without loss of generality, we can consider the cloud server as a special EN, i.e., EN 00, co-located with the macro base station. MUs can connect to the cloud server either through ENs or directly with the macro base station. Each MU can be associated with one or more ENs [38]. For example, in Fig. 1, MU 444, which lies in the overlapping coverage areas of EN 111 and EN 222, can upload its local model to either one of these ENs.

3.1 Federated Learning

To construct and share the global model, the goal is to find the model parameter ùê∞‚àà‚Ñùdùê∞superscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} which minimizes the following global loss function in a distributed manner where data is locally stored at MUs:

where n=‚àëi=1Knkùëõsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêæsubscriptùëõùëòn=\sum_{i=1}^{K}n_{k}, Œæùúâ\xi is the regularizing parameter and r‚Äã(ùê∞)ùëüùê∞r(\mathbf{w}) is a deterministic penalty function [39]. Here, lisubscriptùëôùëñl_{i} is the loss function at data sample iùëñi. To solve the problem (1), one can either implement the (a) primal only method or the (b) primal-dual method. Since both FedAvg and CoCoA are widely adopted, e.g., [4, 22, 8, 9, 10, 23, 24, 25, 26], in this paper, we consider both of them in our design.

    Steps 1-3 are repeated until convergence.

3.2 Communication Model

We then introduce the communication model for multi-user access. For each FL iteration, the cloud node will select a set of users ùí¶tsuperscriptùí¶ùë°\mathcal{K}^{t} at each iteration tùë°t. Here, how to select the best MUs at each learning round is out of the scope of this paper 111The learner selection in FL can be based on the quality or significance of information or location learners [8, 9, 10].. All users consent about their models‚Äô structure, such as a specific neural network design. Hence, let Dùê∑D denote the data size of model parameters:

D=(d+1)√óCodeword‚Äãlength,ùê∑ùëë1Codewordlength\displaystyle D=(d+1)\times\mathrm{Codeword~{}length}, (8)

where dùëëd is defined as the number of parameters mentioned as the length of ùê∞ktsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëòùë°\mathbf{w}_{k}^{t} or Œî‚ÄãùêØktŒîsuperscriptsubscriptùêØùëòùë°\Delta\mathbf{v}_{k}^{t}.

3.2.1 Global Model Broadcasting

Since the downlink data rate capacity WdsuperscriptùëäùëëW^{d} of the cloud node is much larger than that of an edge node, all users will listen to the cloud node at the model broadcasting step. The latency for broadcasting the global model is Td=DWdsuperscriptùëádùê∑superscriptùëäùëëT^{\mathrm{d}}=\frac{D}{W^{d}}.

(10)

After edge nodes receive local models, there are two methods considered in this paper. Let Œ≥msubscriptùõæùëö\gamma_{m} denote the transmission latency between edge node mùëöm and the cloud node. Tmusubscriptsuperscriptùëáuùëö\displaystyle T^{\mathrm{u}}_{m} =maxk‚ààùí¶m‚Å°{Tmu,fr}+Œ≥m.absentsubscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶ùëösubscriptsuperscriptùëáufrùëösubscriptùõæùëö\displaystyle=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{m}}{\Big{\{}T^{\mathrm{u,\rm{fr}}}_{m}\Big{\}}}+\gamma_{m}. (12)

Remark 1.

Selecting the primal method or the primal-dual method does not impact the amount of data sent by each user per iteration. The reason is that instead of sending ùê∞kt‚àà‚Ñùdsuperscriptsubscriptùê∞ùëòùë°superscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbf{w}_{k}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, each user sends Œî‚ÄãùêØkt‚àà‚ÑùdŒîsuperscriptsubscriptùêØùëòùë°superscript‚Ñùùëë\Delta\mathbf{v}_{k}^{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} having the same size dùëëd. Thus, in the scenarios where the system chooses primal method in initial iterations and primal-dual method later as in [28] the computation of the total uplink latency remains unchanged.

3.3 Local Processing Model

Let cksubscriptùëêùëòc_{k} (cycles/sample) be the number of processing cycles of MU kùëòk to execute one sample of data, which assumes to be measured offline and known a prior [25]. Denoting the central processing unit (CPU) frequency of MU kùëòk by fksubscriptùëìùëòf_{k} (cycles/s), the computation time for the local training update at MU kùëòk over LùêøL local iterations is given by

tkcp=Lk‚Äãck‚Äãnkfk.superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpsubscriptùêøùëòsubscriptùëêùëòsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëìùëò\displaystyle t_{k}^{\rm{cp}}=L_{k}\frac{c_{k}n_{k}}{f_{k}}. (15)

Here, LksubscriptùêøùëòL_{k} depends on the number of training passes that each client makes over its local dataset on each round, number of local data samples, and the local minibatch size [4]. Note that tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} can be estimated by each MU before joining FL. Thus, the MEC knows tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} as a prior. Since data generated by mobile users usually follow the power law [40, 41], we assume that tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} also follows the power law. Let tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} be lower bounded and upper bounded by tmincpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\min}^{\rm{cp}} and tmaxcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}, respectively. The probability density of computing time is

p‚Äã(tcp)=Œ≤‚àí1tmincp‚Äã(tcptmincp)‚àíŒ≤.ùëùsuperscriptùë°cpùõΩ1superscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsuperscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpùõΩ\displaystyle p(t^{\rm{cp}})=\frac{\beta-1}{t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}}\Bigg{(}\frac{t^{\rm{cp}}}{t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}}\Bigg{)}^{-\beta}. (16)

With several real datasets [41], it is observed that Œ≤‚àà[1.47,2.46]ùõΩ1.472.46\beta\in[1.47,2.46]. Here, we set Œ≤ùõΩ\beta at 1.61.61.6, tmincpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\min}^{\rm{cp}} at 0.20.20.2. We also limit the maximum value of tcpsuperscriptùë°cpt^{\rm{cp}} at 808080s.

4 In-Network Computation User Scheduling

To minimize the training time of the FL systems, we aim to minimize the latency that includes both up/down-link communication and computing latency for each FL iteration. Specifically, the latency per iteration depends on how we schedule the MUs to upload their updates, how the local model/updates from MUs are routed to the server, and how allocate communications resources for each up-link. Let s‚ààùïäùë†ùïäs\in\mathbb{S} denote a user scheduling scheme and ùïäùïä\mathbb{S} denote the set of all feasible scheduling schemes. The training time minimization problem can be formulated as follows.

mins,ùêÄ,ùêë‚Å°T‚Äã(s,ùêÄ,ùêë),subscriptùë†ùêÄùêëùëáùë†ùêÄùêë\displaystyle\min_{s,\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}}T(s,\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}), (17)

where T‚Äã(s,ùêÄ,ùêë)ùëáùë†ùêÄùêëT(s,\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}) is the training time of one iteration.

For the widely accepted conventional scheduling scheme, denoted by s0subscriptùë†0s_{0}, the network operator begins aggregating users‚Äô models after all users complete their local update step [25]. Its training time for one FL iteration is computed as follows :

T‚Äã(s0,ùêÄ,ùêë)=Td+maxk‚Å°{tkcp}+Tu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë).ùëásubscriptùë†0ùêÄùêësuperscriptùëádsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpsuperscriptùëáuùêÄùêë\displaystyle T(s_{0},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R})=T^{\mathrm{d}}+\max_{k}\{t_{k}^{\rm{cp}}\}+T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}). (18)

This scheduling may suffer serious straggler effect due to slow MUs. We observe that with different distributions of tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}}, we can use different suitable user scheduling schemes. Let us consider two extreme cases where tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} is either densely or dispersedly distributed. We apply two corresponding scheduling schemes with the upper bounds of the training time.

Remark 2.

If the local computing time of users is densely distributed, i.e., tmaxcp‚àítmincp‚â§œµ0‚ÄãTu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë),œµ0‚àà(0,1)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsubscriptitalic-œµ0superscriptùëáuùêÄùêësubscriptitalic-œµ001t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}-t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}\leq\epsilon_{0}T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}),\epsilon_{0}\in(0,1), the network operator could wait for all users finishing updating local model, i.e., the s0subscriptùë†0s_{0} scheduling scheme. The training time in one iteration is then bounded by

T‚Äã(s0,ùêÄ,ùêë)‚â§Td+tmincp+(1+œµ0)‚ÄãTu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë).ùëásubscriptùë†0ùêÄùêësuperscriptùëádsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cp1subscriptitalic-œµ0superscriptùëáuùêÄùêë\displaystyle T(s_{0},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R})\leq T^{\mathrm{d}}+t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+(1+\epsilon_{0})T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}). (19)

We observe that if the difference of local processing time between the slowest and the fastest client is not significant, i.e., tmaxcp‚àítmincp‚â§œµ0‚ÄãTu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë),œµ0‚àà(0,1)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsubscriptitalic-œµ0superscriptùëáuùêÄùêësubscriptitalic-œµ001t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}-t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}\leq\epsilon_{0}T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}),\epsilon_{0}\in(0,1), the user scheduling does not highly impact the training time in one iteration. For example, given 100100100 users and the aggregation time of collecting all models, TusuperscriptùëáuT^{\mathrm{u}}, is 100100100 seconds, if 808080 users finish local processing at the same time after 797979 seconds and 202020 users finish local processing at the same time after 808080 seconds, the training time in one iteration cannot be sooner than Td+79+Tu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë)superscriptùëád79superscriptùëáuùêÄùêëT^{\mathrm{d}}+79+T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}), but can not later than Td+80+Tu‚Äã(ùêÄ,ùêë)superscriptùëád80superscriptùëáuùêÄùêëT^{\mathrm{d}}+80+T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}). Since the upper-bound of the difference of aggregation time between the earliest case and the slowest case is 111 second which is very small compared with the aggregation time. In this case, it does not impact much on the training time.

Remark 3.

Let us rank the local processing time tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} in an increasing order. If the local processing time of users is dispersedly distributed, i.e., min‚Å°|tqcp‚àítq+1cp|‚â•DWu,‚àÄqsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëûcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëû1cpùê∑superscriptùëäùë¢for-allùëû\min|t_{q}^{\rm{cp}}-t_{q+1}^{\rm{cp}}|\geq\frac{D}{W^{u}},\forall q, where qùëûq is the index of the rank, the centralized/cloud server can collect users‚Äô models one by one. The training time in one iteration is then

T‚Äã(s1,ùêÄ,ùêë)=Td+tmaxcp+DWu.ùëásubscriptùë†1ùêÄùêësuperscriptùëádsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpùê∑superscriptùëäùë¢\displaystyle T(s_{1},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R})=T^{\mathrm{d}}+t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}+\frac{D}{W^{u}}. (20)

As an illustrative example, Fig. 2 shows a distribution of tkcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpt_{k}^{\rm{cp}} of 500500500 users following the power law distribution, where tmincpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\min}^{\rm{cp}} and tmaxcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\max}^{\rm{cp}} are 0.20.20.2s and 808080s, respectively. Given this observation, we propose an in-network user scheduling mechanism to mitigate the straggler effect in FL systems in the next section.

4.1 Bipartition User Scheduling Scheme

Our proposed bipartition user scheduling is summarized in Algorithm 1. Specifically, let ùí´1t={k‚ààùí¶t|tkcp‚àà[tmincp,tmincp+Œî‚Äãt]}superscriptsubscriptùí´1ùë°conditional-setùëòsuperscriptùí¶ùë°superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpŒîùë°{\mathcal{P}_{1}^{t}}=\{k\in\mathcal{K}^{t}|t_{k}^{\rm{cp}}\in[t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}},t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+\Delta t]\} be the user partition where tkcp‚àà[tmincp,tmincp+Œî‚Äãt]superscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpŒîùë°t_{k}^{\rm{cp}}\in[t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}},t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+\Delta t] and ùí´2t=ùí¶t‚àñùí´1tsuperscriptsubscriptùí´2ùë°superscriptùí¶ùë°superscriptsubscriptùí´1ùë°{\mathcal{P}_{2}^{t}}=\mathcal{K}^{t}\setminus\mathcal{P}_{1}^{t} denote the user partition of the rest users, at iteration tùë°t. Let Tu‚Äã(ùêÄùí´jt,ùêëùí´jt,ùí´jt)superscriptùëáusubscriptùêÄsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°subscriptùêësuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°superscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A}_{\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}},\mathbf{R}_{\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}},\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}) denote the uplink latency which is returned by a network routing algorithm by aggregating of all users‚Äô models of ùí´jtsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t} under the corresponding uplink routing and bandwidth allocation matrices ùêÄùí´jt,ùêëùí´jtsubscriptùêÄsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°subscriptùêësuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°\mathbf{A}_{\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}},\mathbf{R}_{\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}}, for j‚àà{1,2}ùëó12j\in\{1,2\}. At each iteration tùë°t, we first begin aggregating the global model of ùí´1tsuperscriptsubscriptùí´1ùë°\mathcal{P}_{1}^{t} at time tmincp+Œî‚Äãtsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpŒîùë°t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+\Delta t. If tùí´1t>Td+tmaxcpsubscriptùë°superscriptsubscriptùí´1ùë°superscriptùëádsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\mathcal{P}_{1}^{t}}>T^{\mathrm{d}}+t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}, we aggregate ùí´2tsuperscriptsubscriptùí´2ùë°\mathcal{P}_{2}^{t}. 4.2 System‚Äôs Latency Analysis

We now analyze the training time of the FL system in one iteration resulting from the proposed user scheduling scheme. This bipartition scheduling scheme‚Äôs whole network latency of one FL iteration is computed by

T‚Äã(sb,ùêÄ,ùêë)=Td+max‚Å°{tùí´1t,tmaxcp}+Tu‚Äã(ùêÄùí´2t,ùêëùí´2t,ùí´2t),ùëásubscriptùë†ùëèùêÄùêësuperscriptùëádsubscriptùë°superscriptsubscriptùí´1ùë°superscriptsubscriptùë°cpsuperscriptùëáusubscriptùêÄsuperscriptsubscriptùí´2ùë°subscriptùêësuperscriptsubscriptùí´2ùë°superscriptsubscriptùí´2ùë°\displaystyle{T(s_{b},\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R})}=T^{\mathrm{d}}+\max\{t_{\mathcal{P}_{1}^{t}},t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}\}+T^{\mathrm{u}}(\mathbf{A}_{\mathcal{P}_{2}^{t}},\mathbf{R}_{\mathcal{P}_{2}^{t}},\mathcal{P}_{2}^{t}), (22)

5 In-Network Aggregation Design

We now introduce the in-network aggregation design that allows edge nodes to support the server for addictive weighting users‚Äô local models. Back to early 200020002000s, the concept of in-network computation was well-studied for wireless sensor networks (WSNs), e.g., [16] due to sensors‚Äô limited communications, computing, storage capabilities. The core idea of in-network computation is to design data structures to better represent the information collected/generated at each sensor for each specific application [16]. Analogously, under FL, mobile users also do not transmit their raw data to the server. We then can interpret their local models as their data representation. To obtain the global model, defined in (7), we first design the user packet which plays the role of data representation in a in-network computation solution. This packet design can be tailored to adapt with two FL schemes. Specifically, let œïkt={œïkt‚Äã[0],œïkt‚Äã[1]}superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëòùë°superscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]0superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]1\bm{\phi}_{k}^{t}=\{\phi_{k}^{t}[0],\bm{\phi}_{k}^{t}[1]\} denote the local message of users kùëòk at iteration tùë°t which are generated by following (21).

5.1 Aggregation Function

In this section, we propose a general aggregation function which is suitable for the two methods solving FL problems. If we use the primal method, we observe that

n=‚àëknk=‚àëkœïkt‚Äã[0].ùëõsubscriptùëòsubscriptùëõùëòsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]0\displaystyle n=\sum_{k}n_{k}=\sum_{k}\phi_{k}^{t}[0]. (26)

Similarly, for the primal-dual method, we also observe that

|ùí¶t|superscriptùí¶ùë°\displaystyle|\mathcal{K}^{t}| =‚àëkœïkt‚Äã[0].absentsubscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]0\displaystyle=\sum_{k}\phi_{k}^{t}[0]. (27)

Hence, let zùëßz be a hyperparameter where z=1ùëß1z=1 if we use the primal-dual method and z=0ùëß0z=0 otherwise. To preserve the return of (7), the global model of the cloud at each iteration can be computed from the users‚Äô packets designed in (21) as follows

ùùçt+1=z‚Äãùùçt+‚àëkœïkt‚Äã[0]‚Äãœïkt‚Äã[1]‚àëkœïkt‚Äã[0].superscriptùùçùë°1ùëßsuperscriptùùçùë°subscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]0superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]1subscriptùëòsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-œïùëòùë°delimited-[]0\displaystyle\bm{\psi}^{t+1}=z\bm{\psi}^{t}+\frac{\sum_{k}\phi_{k}^{t}[0]\bm{\phi}_{k}^{t}[1]}{\sum_{k}\phi_{k}^{t}[0]}. (28)

Thus, we now can use (28) as the aggregation function generalized for both primal and primal-dual methods solving FL.

5.2 In-network Aggregation Process with Bipartition User Scheduling Scheme

Under the proposed bipartition scheduling scheme sbsubscriptùë†ùëès_{b}, users are scheduled to aggregate their models in two partitions. In this section, we propose a novel in-network aggregation (INA) process, as illustrated in Fig. 3, that enable edge nodes to support the cloud node in decentralizing the aggregation process. Theorem 2.

(Theorem 222 of [26] as well as Theorem 4.24.24.2 and Theorem 4.34.34.3 of [21]) Assuming that li‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscriptùëôùëñ‚ãÖl_{i}(\cdot) is convex with 1/Œº1ùúá1/\mu-smoothness and r‚Äã(‚ãÖ)ùëü‚ãÖr(\cdot) is 1-strongly convex. Here, Œπ‚Ä≤superscriptùúÑ‚Ä≤\iota^{\prime} is upperbounded by ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°(1/Œ∏g))1‚àíŒ∏lùí™1subscriptùúÉùëî1subscriptùúÉùëô\frac{\mathcal{O}(\log(1/\theta_{g}))}{1-\theta_{l}}, where Œ∏lsubscriptùúÉùëô\theta_{l} is the local accuracy defining at Assumption 4.14.14.1 of [21].

Proof.

From Proposition 1, it can be seen that the INA process always remains the returns of the FL aggregated model for both FedAvg and CoCoA. Thus, if FedAvg is used, Eq. (35) holds by following Theorem 2 of [26]. Similarly, if CoCoA is used, Eq. (36) holds by following Theorem 4.24.24.2 and Theorem 4.34.34.3 of [21]. ‚àé

Remark 4.

In a special case where no user is directly associated with the cloud node, the proposed edge network architecture and the INA process could reduce the traffic and computing overhead at the cloud node by a factor of K/MùêæùëÄK/M in comparison with conventional FL star network topology, where KùêæK is the number of users and MùëÄM is the number of edge nodes.

Proof.

The traffic overhead at the cloud node is proportional to the number of models the cloud node received. For computing overhead, we also assume that the aggregation operation at the cloud runs linearly to the number of received models. Hence, under the conventional FL star network topology, the cloud node receives KùêæK models from its users.

In contrast, with the proposed edge network architecture using the INA, when no user is directly associated with the cloud node, i.e., ùí¶0=‚àÖsubscriptùí¶0\mathcal{K}_{0}=\emptyset, the cloud node only receives MùëÄM aggregated models from the edge nodes. As a result, in practice where K>>Mmuch-greater-thanùêæùëÄK>>M, the two mentioned overheads are reduced by a factor of K/MùêæùëÄK/M. ‚àé

Under the proposed INA process, the transmission latency Œ≥msubscriptùõæùëö\gamma_{m} between an edge node mùëöm and the cloud node is revised. If there is no user associate with an edge node mùëöm, i.e., ‚àëkak‚Äãm=0subscriptùëòsubscriptùëéùëòùëö0\sum_{k}a_{km}=0, Œ≥msubscriptùõæùëö\gamma_{m} is zero. Otherwise, since edge node mùëöm only needs to send the aggregated model the cloud node, Œ≥msubscriptùõæùëö\gamma_{m} is revised as follows

Œ≥m=min‚Å°{DBmbk,D‚Äã‚àëk‚ààùí¶mak‚ÄãmBmbk}.subscriptùõæùëöùê∑subscriptsuperscriptùêµbkùëöùê∑subscriptùëòsubscriptùí¶ùëösubscriptùëéùëòùëösubscriptsuperscriptùêµbkùëö\displaystyle\gamma_{m}=\min\Bigg{\{}\frac{D}{B^{\mathrm{bk}}_{m}},\frac{D\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{m}}a_{km}}{B^{\mathrm{bk}}_{m}}\Bigg{\}}. (37)

6 Network Routing and Resource Allocation Framework for FL

Following the user scheduling scheme and the INA process proposed above, in this section, we aim to optimize the network‚Äô resource allocation and the routing matrices to minimize the uplink aggregation latency in one iteration for a given partition ùí´jtsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}.When the proposed INA process is considered, the joint routing and resource optimization problem for users in ùí´jtsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t} can be written as follows:

‚Ñ±1u::superscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢absent\displaystyle\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u}: minùêÄ,ùêë‚Å°Tu,subscriptùêÄùêësuperscriptùëáu\displaystyle\min_{\mathbf{A},\mathbf{R}}{T^{\mathrm{u}}},
s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle\rm{s.t.}~{} ‚àëm=0Mak‚Äãm=1,‚àÄk‚ààùí´jt,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptùëö0ùëÄsubscriptùëéùëòùëö1for-allùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùí´ùëóùë°\displaystyle\sum_{m=0}^{M}a_{km}=1,\forall k\in{\mathcal{P}_{j}^{t}}, (38a)
‚àëk‚ààK0rk‚Äã0‚â§Wu,subscriptùëòsubscriptùêæ0subscriptùëüùëò0superscriptùëäùë¢\displaystyle\sum_{k\in K_{0}}r_{k0}\leq W^{u}, (38b)

(38e)

The constraints (38a) guarantee that a user can associate with only one edge node in one iteration222A more general network model could be considered. The binary constraints can be replaced by ak‚Äãm‚àà[0,1]subscriptùëéùëòùëö01a_{km}\in[0,1]. However, in that scenario, the proposed in-network aggregation process at edge nodes could run with incomplete models. Those models are then forwarded to the cloud to be aggregated. Consequently, the network suffers extra latency and traffic as penalties. In practice, as Dùê∑D and KùêæK can be significantly large, the penalties make the solution of ak‚Äãmsubscriptùëéùëòùëöa_{km} close to binary.. The constraints (38b) and (38c) ensure that total users‚Äô data rates associated with each edge node or the cloud node must not exceed its bandwidth capacity. Here, the transmission latency between an edge node mùëöm and the cloud node is computed as in (37). The mixed integer non-linear programming problem ‚Ñ±1usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u} is actually NP-Hard. We then propose a highly efficient randomized rounding solution for practical implementation in the next section.

Proposition 2.

‚Ñ±1usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u} is a NP-Hard problem.

Proof.

To prove that ‚Ñ±1usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u} is a NP-Hard problem, we first introduce Lemma 1 and Lemma 2. These two lemmas allow us to transform ‚Ñ±1usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u} into an equivalent Integer Linear Programming, which is then proven to be NP-Hard. Hence, ‚Ñ±1usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±1ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{1}^{u} is also NP-Hard.

Lemma 1.

This formulation is mathematically similar to the makespan minimization problem for parallel machines, which is NP-Hard [43], where the makespan is the completion time of the last task. The Linear Relaxation of ‚Ñ±3usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±3ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{3}^{u} can be expressed as follows:

Let z‚Ä†=[ùêö~‚Ä†,y‚Ä†,Œ≥1‚Ä†,‚Ä¶,Œ≥M‚Ä†]superscriptùëß‚Ä†superscript~ùêö‚Ä†superscriptùë¶‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùõæ1‚Ä†‚Ä¶superscriptsubscriptùõæùëÄ‚Ä†z^{\dagger}=[{\tilde{\mathbf{a}}}^{\dagger},y^{\dagger},\gamma_{1}^{\dagger},\ldots,\gamma_{M}^{\dagger}] denote the optimal solution of ‚Ñ±4usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±4ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{4}^{u}. If all components of ùêÄ‚Ä†superscriptùêÄ‚Ä†{\mathbf{A}}^{\dagger} are binary, it is also the optimal solution to ‚Ñ±2usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±2ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{2}^{u}. Otherwise, to recover binary characteristic of ùêÄùêÄ{\mathbf{A}}, for each row of ùêÄ‚Ä†superscriptùêÄ‚Ä†{\mathbf{A}}^{\dagger}, we randomly round the element ak‚Äãmsubscriptùëéùëòùëöa_{km} to 1 with probability ak‚Äãm‚Ä†superscriptsubscriptùëéùëòùëö‚Ä†{a_{km}}^{\dagger}. The decision is done in an exclusive manner for satisfying constraint (38a). It means that for each row kùëòk, only one element of the row is one, the rest are zeros. For example, let us consider 222 edge nodes and at row kùëòk, assume ak‚Äã0=0.7subscriptùëéùëò00.7a_{k0}=0.7, ak‚Äã1=0.1subscriptùëéùëò10.1a_{k1}=0.1 and ak‚Äã2=0.2subscriptùëéùëò20.2a_{k2}=0.2. 8 Numerical Results

In this section, we carry out simulations to evaluate the performance of the proposed frameworks. We consider a similar setup as in [30], depicted in Fig. 4. Here, M=9ùëÄ9M=9 edge nodes are regularly deployed on a grid network inside a 500√ó500‚Äãm2500500superscriptm2500\times 500~{}\rm{m}^{2} area. K=1000ùêæ1000K=1000 mobile users are uniformly distributed over the edge nodes‚Äô coverage regions (each of 150150150m radius). All mobile users are within the coverage of the cloud node. For each edge node mùëöm, we set the uplink fronthaul capacity to Bmfr=1subscriptsuperscriptùêµfrùëö1B^{\mathrm{fr}}_{m}=1Gbps, the backhaul capacity to Bmbk=1subscriptsuperscriptùêµbkùëö1B^{\mathrm{bk}}_{m}=1Gbps. These settings are inspired by WiFi IEEE 802.11ac standards [45], and data centers interconnection using optical fibers [46]. We also set the cloud uplink and downlink capacities Wu=Wd=2superscriptùëäùë¢superscriptùëäùëë2W^{u}=W^{d}=2Gbps. As in [25], we set tmincpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\min}^{\rm{cp}} and tmaxcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\max}^{\rm{cp}} at 0.20.20.2s and 808080s, respectively. For model aggregation, by default, we investigate our system using ResNet152‚Äôs model size, i.e., D=232ùê∑232D=232 MB [42]. In later simulations, we also investigate our system with different model sizes.

8.1 Algorithm Comparison - Latency Reduction

Fig. 5 compares the one-iteration training time of different algorithms versus the number of users KùêæK. The proposed INC protocol is compared with three other baseline methods, namely:

  • 1.

    ‚ÄúOnly Cloud‚Äù: All KùêæK users‚Äô models are directly aggregated via their direct link to the cloud. Here, models are not forwarded to any edge nodes (ENs).

  • 2.

    ‚ÄúSelect Highest Capacity EN‚Äù: In this greedy-manner framework, each user selects the neighbor EN with the highest uplink data rate capacity.

  • 3.

    ‚ÄúSelect Nearest EN‚Äù: In this greedy-manner framework, each user selects the nearest neighbor EN.

  • 4.

    ‚ÄúINC Solution‚Äù: KùêæK users can associate with the cloud node and edge nodes with INC protocol. The network routing problem ‚Ñ±3usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±3ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{3}^{u} is solved by using Algorithm 2.

  • 5.

    ‚ÄúINC-Lower Bound‚Äù: In this scenario, we use Linear Relaxation to solve ‚Ñ±3usuperscriptsubscript‚Ñ±3ùë¢\mathscr{F}_{3}^{u}. This scenario will provide the lower bound of network latency if the proposed INC protocol is considered.

  • 6.

    ‚ÄúNon-INC LB‚Äù: KùêæK users can associate with the cloud node and edge nodes without the INC protocol. By using Linear Relaxation to solve ùí¨3usuperscriptsubscriptùí¨3ùë¢\mathscr{Q}_{3}^{u}, this method will provide the lower bound of network latency if INA process is not implemented at edge nodes and the cloud node.

Here, users are scheduled by following Algorithm 1. As can be observed in Fig. 5, our proposed algorithm can achieve near optimal performance. When K=5000ùêæ5000K=5000, the latency obtained by the proposed solution is approximately 0.7%percent0.70.7\% higher than that of the INC LB. It implies that our proposed solution can achieve the performance almost the same as that of the lower bound solution even with a high number of users. Only Cloud has the worst performance. For example, when K=5000ùêæ5000K=5000, the network latency of Only Cloud is 472147214721s which is is 1.81.81.8 times higher than that of the second worst one, Select Highest Capacity EN, 251625162516s. The second framework, ‚ÄúSelect Highest Capacity EN‚Äù, provides the second lowest performance due to resource contention. Since users select the highest EN with the highest capacity EN of their neighbor EN set, user locating in the overlapping region of the same set of ENs will select the same EN. As a result, there is a resource contention in the chosen EN. The other greedy-manner, ‚ÄúSelect Nearest EN‚Äù, can achieve better performance. Because users‚Äô positions are randomly distributed, the number of users in each EN‚Äôs coverage is approximately the same. Thus, this framework can achieve an approximated load-balancing solution which is significantly better than the second framework. Last but not least, the gaps between our proposed algorithm with other baselines increase as the number of users KùêæK increases. This clearly shows that our proposed solution is significantly beneficial for very large scale federated learning networks.

Since our algorithm requires to compute the Linear Relaxation results before conducting randomization, its time complexity is higher than those of the baseline methods. Table III summarizes the time complexity of the four frameworks.

In Fig. 6, consider Only Cloud, Non-INC LB and our INC solution, we evaluate the network latency with or without user scheduling mechanism in different models. In the case when the user scheduling mechanism is not considered, all users need to wait until the slowest user finishing it local processing step. They are VGG16, ResNet152, Xception and DenseNet121 whose model sizes are 528528528MB, 232232232MB, 888888MB and 333333MB, respectively. The distribution of p‚Äã(tcp)ùëùsuperscriptùë°cpp(t^{\rm{cp}}) is remained unchanged since we want to focus only on the variation of aggregation latency as Dùê∑D changes. Here, we choose the default setting with K=1000ùêæ1000K=1000. We observe that our user scheduling mechanism can mitigate straggler effects due to slow workers. For example, when we consider ResNet152 model, INC solution saves 28.49%percent28.4928.49\% in comparison with the case where user scheduling mechanism is not considered. Moreover, since the aggregation latency decreases as the model‚Äôs size Dùê∑D decreases, we observe that the latency saving of INC solution w.o User Scheduling to INC solution w. User Scheduling increases then decreases. For example, the saving is 14.63%percent14.6314.63\%, 28.49%percent28.4928.49\%, 38.1838.1838.18 and 20.43%percent20.4320.43\% for VGG16, ResNet152, Xception and DenseNet121, respectively. It implies that as the communication latency decreases, the contribution of the slowest node‚Äôs computing delay increases. Until a certain value Dùê∑D, the slowest node‚Äôs computing delay, which is fixed in this simulation, becomes the major part of the whole network delays. Hence, the saving decreases again.

8.2 Impacts of Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t

In this subsection, we investigate the impacts of Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t on the latency of one learning round. Here, we used the default setting with number of users K=1000ùêæ1000K=1000. As we can see in the above figure, as Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t increases, the number of users in P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1} increases because all users with tkcp‚â§tmincp+Œî‚Äãtsuperscriptsubscriptùë°ùëòcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpŒîùë°t_{k}^{\rm{cp}}\leq t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+\Delta t are assigned to P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1}. It is also the reason why the number of users in P2subscriptùëÉ2P_{2} decreases. As can be seen in Fig. 7, we observe that with small Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t, most of users wait until tmaxcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\max}^{\rm{cp}} to be collected in partition P2subscriptùëÉ2P_{2}. Thus, we can see high latency with small Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t. As Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t increases, more users go to P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1}, thus the latency decreases. When Œî‚ÄãtŒîùë°\Delta t is big enough, the latency rises again because most of users are in P1subscriptùëÉ1P_{1} and their local models have to wait after tmincp+Œî‚Äãtsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpŒîùë°t_{\min}^{\rm{cp}}+\Delta t to be collected. When Œî‚Äãt=tmaxcp=80Œîùë°superscriptsubscriptùë°cp80\Delta t=t_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}=80s, the latency is highest since all users‚Äô models start to be collected after tmaxcpsuperscriptsubscriptùë°cpt_{\max}^{\rm{cp}}.

8.3 Traffic and Computation Reduction at the Cloud Node

In this subsection, using ResNet152‚Äôs model setting, we investigate the uplink traffic and the number of models needed to be aggregated at the cloud node in one learning iteration. We compare three schemes: Only Cloud, Non-INC LB and our INC solution. The number of models needed to be aggregated at the cloud node is proportional to the number of computations here. In Figs. 8, the uplink traffic and the number of computations of Non-INC LB at the cloud node is equal to those of Only Cloud. It is because all models need to be sent to the cloud before being aggregated and edge nodes only forward the models from users to the cloud without INA process. Meanwhile, with INC solution, the two metrics are significantly reduced. For example, when K=5000ùêæ5000K=5000, the traffic is 0.20.20.2TB for our scheme and 1.161.161.16TB for the two others. Our scheme achieves more than 555 times lower traffic than the others. In this simulation, with ResNet152, the number of parameters of each local models is 60,419,9446041994460,419,944. As a result, without the proposed INA process, the cloud node needs to aggregate KùêæK models whose sizes are more 606060 millions elements. This will consume a huge amount of processing and memory resources. As can be seen, the INC solution can reduce the number of models needed to be aggregated at the cloud by more than 555 times.

8.4 Impacts of the number of additional edge nodes‚Äô connectivities

In this subsection, we investigate the impacts of the number extra edge nodes users on the straggler effects due to bad communication links. In this simulation, our system suffers straggler effects when a user‚Äôs all wireless connections are bad. As a result, its model is not able to be aggregated at the cloud node. Without loss of generality, we assume that the networking components of servers, edge nodes or cloud node, have probabilities of being faulted. We define pcloudsubscriptùëùcloudp_{\rm{cloud}} as the outage probability of the cloud. Similarly, we define pedgesubscriptùëùedgep_{\rm{edge}} as the outage probability of a given edge node (here we assume all edge nodes have the same outage probability). Thus, the probability that the system suffers the straggler effect PssubscriptùëÉùë†{P_{s}} is computed as

Ps=pcloud‚Äãpedgev,subscriptPssubscriptùëùcloudsuperscriptsubscriptùëùedgeùë£\displaystyle\mathrm{P_{s}}=p_{\rm{cloud}}p_{\rm{edge}}^{v}, (57)

where vùë£v is the number of extra edge nodes users can connect. As can be observed in Fig. 9, increasing the number of additional edge connectivities can significantly mitigate straggler effects. With pcloud=0.3subscriptùëùcloud0.3p_{\rm{cloud}}=0.3, we can decrease the straggle effects 444 times and 121212 times by providing two additional edge connections for users, with the well-being probabilities of edge node‚Äôs networking component are 0.50.50.5 and 0.70.70.7, respectively.

9 Conclusion and Future Directions

In this article, we proposed a novel edge network architecture to decentralize the communications and computing burden of cloud node in Federated Learning. To that end, we designed an in-network computation protocol (INC) consisting of a user scheduling mechanism, an in-network aggregation process (INA), and an routing algorithm. The in-network aggregation process, which is implemented at edge nodes and cloud node, can adapt two typical methods to solve the distributed machine learning problems. Under the proposed in-network aggregation (INA) framework, we then formulated a joint routing and resource optimization problem, aiming to minimize the aggregation latency. The problem is proved to be NP-Hard. We then derived its near-optimal solution using random rounding with proven performance guarantee. Simulation results showed that the proposed algorithm can achieve more than 99 %percent\% of the optimal solution and significantly outperforms all other baseline schemes without INA. The proposed scheme becomes even more effective (in reducing the latency and straggler effects) when more edge nodes are available. Moreover, we also showed that the INA framework not only help reduce training latency in FL but also reduce significantly reduce the traffic load to the cloud node. By embedding the computing/aggregation tasks at edge nodes and leveraging the multi-layer edge-network architecture, the INA framework can enable large-scale FL.
